translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair lady, by your leave, I come by note to give and to receive.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: My lady, with your permission, this note authorizes me to give myself to you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Do you think you have a couple of fools on your hands?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair Leda’s daughter had a thousand wooers; Then well one more may fair Bianca have.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The beautiful Helen of Troy had a thousand suitors.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair lovers, you are fortunately met.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You pretty lovers are lucky you met me here.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Fair princess, you have missed some good sport.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair sir, and you, my merry mistress, That with your strange encounter much amazed me, My name is called Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa, And bound I am to Padua, there to visit A son of mine which long I have not seen.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Well, sir, and you, witty lady, who gave me quite a turn with your strange talk. My name is Vincentio, my hometown

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair sir, I pity her And wish, for her sake more than for mine own, My fortunes were more able to relieve her.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Dear sir, I pity the lady and wish more for her sake than my own.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young boy, I wish I could make you believe that I am in love.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have Some patient leisure to excuse myself.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You who are beautiful beyond words, calm down and let me explain myself.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fairly spoke.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You have said it well.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Fairy King, attend, and mark.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Listen, Fairy King.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, e'en with losing his wits.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Yes, that one.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: He rushed away on serious business.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, he tonight hath boarded a land carrack.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Tonight he boarded a treasure ship.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, her privates we.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Yes, we are the privates in her army.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, here’s an English tailor come hither for stealing out of a French hose.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Maybe it is an English tailor who liked to skimp on the fabric for people’s clothes.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Yes, I know her age down to the hour.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, I know not what to say.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: What do you say, James?  Well, I do not know what to say.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, I saw it not, but I felt it hot in her breath.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Honestly, I did not see it, but I felt it in her hot breath.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, I’ll home tomorrow, Sir Toby.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Listen, I am going home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, like enough.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Yes, that is quite likely.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, niece, you tax Signor Benedick too much, but he’ll be meet with you, I doubt it not.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I am sure he will get even with you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, no, as you may season it in the charge.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: No, not if you say it right.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace To breakfast once, forth of my company.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Name one.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of “father” Pantingly forth as if it pressed her heart, Cried, “Sisters, sisters!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Once or twice she sighed and said, “father,” as if the word were pressing on her chest.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, sir, so-so.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Well, so-so.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, sir, you need not fear.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I assure you, sir, there is nothing to be afraid of.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Actually, I am still feeling some pangs of conscience.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, stay here this night.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, that was not so well.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old gentleman’s saying.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, there has been much to do on both sides, and the nation holds it no sin to tar them to controversy.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, we may put up our pipes and be gone.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Faith, we met and found the quarrel was upon the seventh cause.

translations.Shakespearean Text: First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnishèd with plate and gold, Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry, In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns, In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass, and all things that belong To house or housekeeping.

translations.Shakespearean Text: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow to a point.

translations.Shakespearean Text: First, he commends him to your noble self.

translations.Shakespearean Text: First, if all obstacles were cut away And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth, Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, That I would rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid And in the vapor of my glory smothered.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Five shillings to one on ’t, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him—marry, not without the Prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I will bet any man who knows the law five shillings on it.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece, Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia, And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus, Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought Or that or any place that harbors men.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For by the way I’ll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talked of, To part the queen’s proud kindred from the prince.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For do but stand upon the foaming shore, The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds, The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, Seems to cast water on the burning bear, And quench the guards of th' ever-fixèd pole.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: For my brother Edward’s sake.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For England his approaches makes as fierce As waters to the sucking of a gulf.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The king of England’s approach is as forceful as a whirlpool.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For every minute is expectancy Of more arrivance.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For Falstaff, he is dead, and we must earn therefore.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For Hamlet and the trifling of his favor, Hold it a fashion and a toy in blood, A violet in the youth of primy nature, Forward, not permanent, sweet, not lasting, The perfume and suppliance of a minute.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: As for Hamlet and his attentions to you, just consider it a flirtation, the temporary phase of a hot-blooded youth.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For he is, sure, i' th' island.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I am sure he is somewhere on the island.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The wooing is like a Scottish jig: hot and fast and full of whimsy and illusion.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For heaven’s sake, help me!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: For heaven’s sake, help me!

translations.Shakespearean Text: For him, I think not on him.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For himself to mar,” quoth he?

translations.Shakespearean Text: For his bounty, There was no winter in ’t, an autumn ’twas That grew the more by reaping.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For his thoughts, Would they were blanks, rather than fill’d with me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For his valor cannot carry his discretion, and the fox carries the goose.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For I can give his humor the true bent, And I will bring him to the Capitol.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For I mine own gained knowledge should profane If I would time expend with such a snipe But for my sport and profit.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For I will make him tell the tale anew Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when He hath, and is again to cope your wife.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For if such actions may have passage free, Bond-slaves and pagans shall our statesmen be.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For if the Jew do cut but deep enough, I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a good kissing carrion— Have you a daughter?

translations.Shakespearean Text: For if thou dost intend Never so little show of love to her, Thou shalt aby it.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For in all the play There is not one word apt, one player fitted.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird?

translations.Shakespearean Text: For it is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being poured out of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty the other.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For lead?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: For lead?

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You must understand, Silius, that it is better to leave something undone than achieve too much fame in your superior’s absence.

translations.Shakespearean Text: For Lord Hamlet, Believe so much in him that he is young, And with a larger tether may he walk Than may be given you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: I have neither the scholar’s melancholy, which is emulation; nor the musician’s, which is fantastical; nor the courtier’s, which is proud; nor the soldier’s, which is ambitious; nor the lawyer’s, which is politic; nor the lady’s, which is nice; nor the lover’s, which is all these, but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels, in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous sadness.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I do not have the proud melancholy of a courtier or the ambitious melancholy of a soldier or the calculated melancholy of a lawyer.

translations.Shakespearean Text: I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.

translations.Shakespearean Text: I have no exquisite reason for ’t, but I have reason good enough.

translations.Shakespearean Text: I have no food for thee.

translations.Shakespearean Text: O Cicero, I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen Th' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threatening clouds, But never till tonight, never till now, Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Cicero, I have experienced storms in which the angry winds split old oak trees, and I have seen the ocean swell, rage, and foam

translations.Shakespearean Text: O dear!

translations.Shakespearean Text: O gentle lady, do not put me to ’t, For I am nothing, if not critical.

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Oh, Antonio, I am sorry I caused you so much trouble.

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Oh, heavenly mixture!

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I wish we could unmask scoundrels like that, and give a whip to every good man to beat them senseless with.

translations.Shakespearean Text: O murderous slumber, Layst thou thy leaden mace upon my boy That plays thee music?—Gentle knave, good night.

translations.Shakespearean Text: O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Oh, my heart!

translations.Shakespearean Text: O noble English, that could entertain With half their forces the full pride of France And let another half stand laughing by, All out of work and cold for action!

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are bound to the like.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are enough yet living in the field To smother up the English in our throngs, If any order might be thought upon.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are for you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Sounds good to us.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are friends.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are friends.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I am happy the Dauphin has such a good sense of humor.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are haunted.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are being haunted.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are in God’s hand, brother, not in theirs.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are in God’s hands, brother, not in theirs.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are men, my liege.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are men, my lord.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are no tyrant, but a Christian king, Unto whose grace our passion is as subject As is our wretches fettered in our prisons.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are resolved, my lord.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are sent To give thee from our royal master thanks, Only to herald thee into his sight, Not pay thee.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The king sent us to give you his thanks and to bring you to him.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are spoiled and yonder he is!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: There he is!

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are such stuff As dreams are made on, and our little life Is rounded with a sleep.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are all made of dreams, and our life stretches from birth to death.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are the makers of manners, Kate, and the liberty that follows our places stops the mouth of all find- faults, as I will do yours for upholding the nice fashion of your country in denying me a kiss.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You and I, Kate, we are the makers of custom, and the freedom that goes with our position silences all who would criticize us.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are the queen’s abjects and must obey.— Brother, farewell.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Farewell, brother.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are their parents and original.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are responsible for this.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are three of them.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are three of them.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are two lions littered in one day, And I the elder and more terrible.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are undone, lady, we are undone!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are ruined, lady. We are ruined.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are very sorry for’t.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are yet but young in deed.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are still just beginners when it comes to crime.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We are, my lord, and come to have the warrant That we may be admitted where he is.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are, my lord.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We being strangers here, how dar’st thou trust So great a charge from thine own custody?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are strangers here.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We both have fed as well, and we can both Endure the winter’s cold as well as he.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We both have eaten as well, and we can both endure the cold winter as well.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We came crying hither.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I came here crying.

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We came here to fight against you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We cannot all be masters, nor all masters Cannot be truly followed.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We cannot be here and there too.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We do not know.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We do not know.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We do not mean the coursing snatchers only, But fear the main intendment of the Scot, Who hath been still a giddy neighbor to us.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: What we have to worry about is a full-scale invasion from Scotland.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We do, my lord.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Yes, sir.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We doubt it nothing.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We do not doubt it.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We doubt not now But every rub is smoothèd on our way.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I am now sure that every bump in the road has been removed.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We doubt not of a fair and lucky war, Since God so graciously hath brought to light This dangerous treason lurking in our way To hinder our beginnings.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I have no doubt that it will be a swift and successful war, since God so graciously exposed this dangerous plot.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We first address towards you, who with this king Hath rivaled for our daughter.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You have been competing with this king for my daughter.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We follow thee.—Juliet, the county stays.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We will follow you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We found him in the churchyard.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We found him in the churchyard.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two old men without teeth.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We were about to have our noses snapped off by two old men with no teeth.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We had much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: There were many even more memorable feasts.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.— Is it e'en so?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We have a dessert coming up.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We have beat him to his camp.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We have driven him all the way back to his camp.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We have been praying for our husbands' welfare, Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We have been praying for our husbands' welfare.

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We have been looking for him everywhere.

translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We have finished our business.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We have engaged ourselves too far.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We have here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We here attend you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: We hope to make the sender blush at it.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will find me ready to do that, sir, if you give me a reason.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have anything.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You can have anything you want.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have gold To pay the petty debt twenty times over.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I will give you enough gold to pay back your debt twenty times over.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have leave.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We will let you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have letters from me to my son In your behalf, to meet you on the way.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I will write to my stepson Richmond on your behalf, so that he will meet you on the way.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall Have letters from me to some friends that will Sweep your way for you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I will give you letters of introduction to some friends of mine who will help you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have none ill, sir, for I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will not get any bad cooks from me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have ransom.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: There is a ransom.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have some part of your will.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will get some of what you want.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have the mustard Or else you get no beef of Grumio.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will take the mustard or you will get no beef from Grumio.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You can argue as much as you like when there is nothing else to do.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will have wine enough, my lord, soon.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall hear me.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will listen to me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall hear more by midnight.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will hear more from me by midnight.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall hear more.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: He will tell you more of the story.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall know more hereafter.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will know more about it later.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall mark Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave That (doting on his own obsequious bondage) Wears out his time much like his master’s ass For naught but provender, and when he’s old, cashiered.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Look at the devoted servants who work for their masters their whole lives for nothing but their food, and then when they get old they are terminated.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall never take her without her answer unless you take her without her tongue.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will never find her without an answer unless you find her without a tongue.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not choose but drink before you go.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You must not go without having a drink first.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not find, Though you be therein curious, the least cause For what you seem to fear.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will not find any cause for anxiety, even if you look for one.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not gauge me By what we do tonight.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You cannot judge me based on what I do tonight.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not go, my lord.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are not going, sir.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not go.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are not going anywhere.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not in your funeral speech blame us, But speak all good you can devise of Caesar, And say you do ’t by our permission.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will not blame us in your funeral speech, but will say all the good you want to about Caesar and that you do it by our permission

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not seal to such a bond for me!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: No, you cannot sign a contract like that for me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall not stir out of your house today.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are not leaving the house today.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will wear a mask, and you can make your voice as high as you want.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall read us the will, Caesar’s will.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You have to read us the will, Caesar’s will.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall see anon how the murderer gets the love of Gonzago’s wife.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will see shortly how the murderer wins the love of Gonzago’s wife.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall try but one fall.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You get only one round.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall, Mark Antony.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You may, Mark Antony.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You shall, my lord.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will, my lord.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You should ask me what time o' day.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should ask me what time of day it is.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You should be ruled and led By some discretion that discerns your state Better than you yourself.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should let others take care of you and submit to people who know better than you do what is good for you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You should for that have reprehended him.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should have reprimanded him for that.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You should hear reason.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should listen to reason.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should have run up to her, unleashed a few excellent quips invented on the spot, and rendered the young man speechless.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You slave, you cur!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You scoundrel!

translations.Shakespearean Text: You speak all your part at once, cues and all.—Pyramus, enter.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You just said all your lines at once, cues and all.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You speak not as you think.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You cannot say what you are saying.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are trying to trick me, my lord.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You speak to Casca, and to such a man That is no fleering telltale.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Say no more.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You speak too bitterly.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Just listen this once.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You spoke not with her since?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Have you not spoken to her since then?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You kick me out, he kicks me back.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You stand amazed, But be of comfort.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Do not worry about me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You stand.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are standing.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You stayed well by ’t in Egypt.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I see you survived your time in Egypt.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You strike my people, and your disordered rabble Make servants of their betters.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You hit my servants, and your disorderly mob of knights treat their superiors like servants.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You sulfurous and thought-executing fires, Vaunt-couriers of oak-cleaving thunderbolts, Singe my white head!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Let quick sulfurous lightning, strong enough to split enormous trees and singe the white hair on my head.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You sunburnt sicklemen of August weary, Come hither from the furrow and be merry.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You tanned fieldworkers who are so tired of August’s labors, get out of the dirt and come rejoice with us.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You swore to me when I did give it you That you would wear it till your hour of death, And that it should lie with you in your grave.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You swore to me when I gave it to you that you would wear it until you died, and that it would be buried with you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You take my house when you do take the prop That doth sustain my house.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You take my house away when you take the money I need for upkeep.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You take my life When you do take the means whereby I live.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You take my life when you take away my means of making a living.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You take pleasure then in the message?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: So you took pleasure in bringing me this message?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You take your pennyworths now.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should take your beauty sleep now.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You talk!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Do not be silly.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You tallow face!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You pale face.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You taught me first to beg, and now methinks You teach me how a beggar should be answered.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: First you taught me how to beg, and now I think you are teaching me how a beggar should be answered.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You taught me language, and my profit on ’t Is I know how to curse.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You taught me language, and all I can do with it is curse.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Tell us about this wrestling.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You the like loss?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Have you suffered a loss like mine?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You think I’ll weep?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You expect me to cry?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You seem to think no one outside of your bedroom knows what you wish.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You think of him too much.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You think about him too much.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You thought because he could not speak English in the native garb, he could not therefore handle an English cudgel.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You thought because he did not speak English like a native, he couldn't handle an English club.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You told a lie, an odious, damnèd lie.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Then you told a lie, a sick, wicked lie.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You told me so.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: That is correct.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You told me you salute not at the court but you kiss your hands.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You told me that you do not salute at the court but kiss hands.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You touched my vein at first.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You were right the first time.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You tremble and look pale.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are pale and trembling.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You understand me?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Understand?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You use this dalliance to excuse Your breach of promise to the Porpentine.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are using this as an excuse for not showing up at the Porcupine like you promised.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You were best go in.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You would better go inside.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You were best knock louder.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You would better knock louder.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You were best to tell Antonio what you hear— Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should tell Antonio what you hear, but do not do it suddenly, because it might upset him.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise By all of us, and the fair soul herself Weighed between loathness and obedience, at Which end o' th' beam should bow.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We all begged you not to go ahead with those marriage plans, and your lovely daughter struggled between disgust at marrying an African and desire to obey you

translations.Shakespearean Text: You were sent for, and there is a kind of confession in your looks which your modesties have not craft enough to color.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You were sent for.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You were the word of war.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: They said they were acting for you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You were to blame, I must be plain with you, To part so slightly with your wife’s first gift, A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You were wrong to give away your wife’s first gift so thoughtlessly.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You whoreson malt-horse drudge!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You bastard workhorse drudge!

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will answer, “The slaves are ours.” So do I answer you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: No, you would answer, “The slaves are ours.” And that is how I am answering you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid: That’s your device.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will pretend to be a schoolmaster and offer to teach the girl.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will be whipped.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will be whipped.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will compel me, then, to read the will?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You force me to read the will, then?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will live in luxury with Gremio.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will lose this wager, my lord.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are going to lose this bet, my lord.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will never run mad, niece.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will never fall victim to Benedick’s charms, my niece.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will not then?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will not, then?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you, there is such odds in the man.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will not enjoy it much, I can tell you, the odds are against this young man.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You were supposed to be proving that there is not time for everything.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You would be satisfied?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You want proof?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You would give the moon a shove if it got stuck five weeks in its orbit.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You would say so, master, if your garments were thin.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: If your clothes were as thin as mine, you would feel the air.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You would seem to know my stops.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I do not know how.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You wrong me every way.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You wrong me in every way.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You wrong me more, sir, in denying it.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You wrong me even more, sir, by denying it.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You wrong me, Brutus.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You wrong me, Brutus.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You wrong me, Signior Gremio.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Please, Signior Gremio.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You wronged yourself to write on behalf of such a man.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, as your business and desire shall point you— For every man has business and desire, Such as it is—and for my own poor part, Look you, I’ll go pray.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You go and take care of your business, since everybody has some business to take care of, whatever it is worth.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, constable, are to present the Prince’s own person.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are representing the Prince himself.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, cousin.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You, niece.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, mistress, all this coil is long of you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: All this fighting is because of you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You, Nick Bottom, have been cast as Pyramus.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, Pyramus' father.—Myself, Thisbe’s father.—Snug the joiner, you, the lion’s part.—And I hope here is a play fitted.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I hope this play is well cast now.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, Roderigo!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You, Roderigo!

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, sir?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You, sir?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, uncivil lady, To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars My soul the faithfull’st off'rings have breathed out That e'er devotion tendered—what shall I do?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I breathed from my soul the most faithful offerings to your ungrateful altars that any devoted person has ever offered.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, you, ay, you!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You!

translations.Shakespearean Text: You, you, sirrah, where’s my daughter?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You, sir, where is my daughter?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You!

translations.Shakespearean Text: You.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’d be king o' th' isle, sirrah?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You wanted to be king of the island, sir?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll “never trust his word after.” Come, ’tis a foolish saying.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will never trust his word again.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll ask me why I rather choose to have A weight of carrion flesh than to receive Three thousand ducats.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are going to ask me why I would rather have a pound of decaying flesh than three thousand ducats.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll be sick tomorrow For this night’s watching.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will be sick tomorrow because you have stayed up all night.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll bear me a bang for that, I fear.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will get a blow from me for that, I think.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: If I break the door down, you will be sorry for this.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll find it otherwise, I assure you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are wrong about that, I assure you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll have coursers for cousins and gennets for germans.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your whole family will be ruined.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll have your nephews neigh to you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your sons will neigh to you like horses.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll heat my blood.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will make me angry.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll let us in, I hope?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Are you going to let us in?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll not endure him!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I will not tolerate him.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll pay me the eight shillings I won of you at betting?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Are you going to pay the eight shillings I won from you in a bet?

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ll win two days upon me.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will get there two days before me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’re fall’n into a princely hand.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are in the charge of an honorable man.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’re much deceived.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are mistaken about all that.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’re sad, Signior Balthasar.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Signior Balthasar, you look upset.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’re welcome hither.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Nice to see you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’re welcome, sir, and he for your good sake.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You and he are both welcome, sir.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ve said, sir.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: That is the truth, sir.

translations.Shakespearean Text: You’ve strange serpents there?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Do you have unusual snakes?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young boys and girls Are level now with men.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young boys and girls are equal to men.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young budding virgin, fair and pure, where are you off to?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young Prince Edward is still alive. What do you think I should say next?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland, To th' ambassadors of England gives This warlike volley.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young Fortinbras, returning from Poland, is firing his guns to greet the English ambassadors.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young fry of treachery!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: What is that, you runt?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your years.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young gentleman, you are too bold for your age.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young man, have you challenged Charles the Wrestler?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young men’s love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young men love with their eyes, not with their hearts.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young Romeo is it?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Is it young Romeo?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Young son, it argues a distempered head So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young man, something is wrong if you are getting out of bed this early.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Younger than she are happy mothers made.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Girls younger than she often marry and become happy mothers.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Younger than you Here in Verona, ladies of esteem Are made already mothers.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Here in Verona there are girls younger than you—girls from noble families—who have already become mothers.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.   Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Callow youth, you do not yet know how to love.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your  It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss before they are married, would she say?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: It is not the custom for maids in France to kiss before they are married, is that what she says?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your speech is more refined than I would expect in such a remote place as this.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your answer to that?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your answer?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Sir, I am puzzled by what you just said.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your bedchamber.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your bedroom.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Better men than you have heard me speak my mind, and if you can’t take it, then you should plug your ears.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your betters, sir.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your superiors.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your brother Gloucester hates you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Richard, the duke of Gloucester, hates you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your brother is but young and tender, and, for your love I would be loath to foil him, as I must for my own honor if he come in.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your brother is young and inexperienced, and because of my affection for him, I would hate to crush him.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your brother the Bastard is fled from Messina.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your brother Don John the Bastard has run away from Messina.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your brother—no, no brother—yet the son— Yet not the son, I will not call him son— Of him I was about to call his father Hath heard your praises, and this night he means To burn the lodging where you use to lie, And you within it.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Oliver, your brother, is not your brother; and yet he is the son.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your cake there is warm within; you stand here in the cold.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The food inside is warm, but you are out here freezing.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your case is better.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your case is better than that.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your castle is surprised, your wife and babes Savagely slaughtered.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your wife and children were savagely slaughtered.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your cause of sorrow Must not be measured by his worth, for then It hath no end.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your grief should not be equal to his worth, because then your sorrow would never end.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your charm so strongly works 'em That if you now beheld them, your affections Would become tender.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your magic spell has such an effect on them that if you saw them now, you would feel sorry for them.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your children shall be kings.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your children will be kings.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your children were vexation to your youth, But mine shall be a comfort to your age.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your children caused you trouble in your youth, but mine will bring you comfort in your old age.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your commission’s ready.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your authorization is ready.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your constancy Hath left you unattended.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You have lost your resolve.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: My lady Olivia, your niece, disapproves of your late-night partying.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your crown’s awry.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your crown is crooked.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bellied Hollander—Drink, ho!—are nothing to your English.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The Danes, the Germans, and the Dutch are nothing compared to the English.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your daughter here the princes left for dead.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The princes left your daughter for dead.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, in one night fourscore ducats.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I also heard that your daughter spent eighty ducats in Genoa one night.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your dinner, and the generous islanders By you invited, do attend your presence.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The nobles of Cyprus whom you invited to dinner are waiting for you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your ear is good.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your ear is good.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves, And desperately are dead.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your eldest daughters destroyed themselves and died in despair.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Emperor Continues still a Jove.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Emperor is still a king among gods.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your eyes are lodestars, and your tongue’s sweet air More tunable than lark to shepherd’s ear When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your eyes are like stars, and your voice is more musical than a shepherd’s song is to a shepherd in the springtime.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your eyes do menace me.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your eyes look threatening.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: When fools cry, you remain stony.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your face, my thane, is as a book where men May read strange matters.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your face betrays strange feelings, my lord, and people will be able to read it like a book.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your father’s sons would make excellent husbands if only a girl could catch one for herself.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your father was an extremely moral man, and religious people get odd ideas on their deathbeds.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your features, Lord warrant us!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your features, God help us.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your fortunes are alike.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your fortunes are the same.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your friends are up and buckle on their armor.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your friends are up and buckling on their armor.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your friends at Pomfret, they are the ones who need a priest.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your gentleness shall force More than your force move us to gentleness.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Gentlemanly manners have more sway around here than force.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The stuff you had at the Centaur, sir.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Grace attended to their sugared words But looked not on the poison of their hearts.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Grace heard their saccharine words, but did not take note of their poisonous intentions.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Grace does me as great honors as can be desired in the hearts of his subjects.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Grace does me as great an honor as could be wished by any of his subjects.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your grace hath laid the odds o' th' weaker side.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You have bet on the weaker fencer.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Grace is too costly to wear every day.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are too expensive to wear every day.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Grace may do your pleasure.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Grace can do whatever he wants.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You, I think, would know what he is thinking.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your graces are right welcome.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Both of you are welcome here.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your grandfather of famous memory, an’t please your Majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales, as I have read in the chronicles, fought a most prave pattle here in France.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: If I may say so, your Majesty, your grandfather and your great-uncle Edward, the Black Prince of Wales—or so I have read

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your hand, Leonato.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Give me your hand, Leonato.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your hands, come then.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Don’t be shy, shake hands with me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: It is like half your soul has been ripped out.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your heart’s desires be with you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I hope you get what you desire.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Highness bade me ask for it today.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Highness told me to ask for my commission today.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Highness told me I should post before.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Highness just told me that I should ride there before you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your honor calls you hence.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your honor is the reason you are leaving.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your honor is most welcome.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are welcome.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Honor wins bad humors.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Honor’s is unhealthy talk.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Honor’s players, hearing your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy, For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Honor’s actors, hearing of your recovery, have come to perform a pleasing comedy for you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your houses!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Curse your families.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your husband being troubled with a shrew Measures my husband’s sorrow by his woe.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your husband, being saddled with a shrew, projects his own suffering onto my husband.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your mother is coming to your bedroom.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your lady, sir, your lady.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your wife, sir, your wife.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You should have a guard nearby if he comes in here, because he is clearly disturbed.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your letters did withhold our breaking forth Till we perceived both how you were wrong led And we in negligent danger.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I did not write about breaking the alliance with Antony until I saw how dangerous it would be to keep postponing preparations.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your lips will feel them the sooner.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You will feel them more quickly.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You look pale and wild as if you are going to hurt yourself.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your lord does know my mind.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your lord knows what I think.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Welcome to Denmark, my lord.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your lordship speaks most infallibly of him.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You speak absolutely correctly, sir.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your loss is as yourself, great, and you bear it As answering to the weight.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are a remarkable person and your loss is equally remarkable.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, 'Where is your mother?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your love says, like an honorable gentleman, "Where is your mother?"

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous— Where is your mother?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your love says, like an honorable gentleman who is courteous, kind, handsome, and, I believe, virtuous. Where is your mother

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your loves, as mine to you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Give me your love instead, as I give you mine.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Majesty came not like yourself.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Majesty did not present yourself as the king.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Majesty says very true.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Majesty is quite right.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Majesty shall mock at me.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Majesty shall mock me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Majesty, hear now, saving your Majesty’s manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy knave it is.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your Majesty, see here if it will not offend your Grace. What a complete, rascally, beggarly, lousy rat.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your man and you are marvelous merry, sir.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You and your servant are very funny.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your mind may change.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You may change your mind later.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your mistress bears well.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your mistress is a good mount.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your mistress sent for me to come to dinner?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your mother.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your mother.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your name, I pray you, friend?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: What is your name?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your name, sir, truly.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Tell us your name, sir, truthfully.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your names?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: What are your names?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your old smock brings forth a new petticoat, and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The only tears you should shed in this case are the kind you might get from holding an onion to your nose.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your overwhelming kindness makes me weep.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You could not prevent her from dying someday, but heaven will give her eternal life.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I appreciate your frankness and your brevity.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: For when you cut your shin.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your power and your command is taken off And Cassio rules in Cyprus.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are stripped of your power and your command, and Cassio will govern Cyprus.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your praise has beaten you home.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your reason?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Why not?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your reason.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Explain.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your answers are too shallow and too hasty.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your reproof is something too round.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your scolding is somewhat exaggerated.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your royal father’s murdered.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your royal father is murdered.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your royal preparation Makes us hear something.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your preparation for war sounds like something.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your rye-straw hats put on, And these fresh nymphs encounter every one In country footing.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Put your straw hats on, have some fun, and dance with these young nymphs.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: The Egyptian snake is born when the sun shines on the Nile mud, just like the crocodile.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your servant Kent.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your servant Kent.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your servant shall do so.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I am at your service.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your servants ever Have theirs, themselves, and what is theirs in compt, To make their audit at your highness' pleasure, Still to return your own.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: We are your servants, your highness, and as always our house and everything in it is at your disposal, for after all, we keep

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your servants tend.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your servants are waiting.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your shoes is not so good.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your shoes are in pretty bad shape.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your sister is the better soldier.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your sister is the better soldier of the two.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your son and daughter found this trespass worth The shame which here it suffers.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: That is why your daughter and son-in-law are punishing me shamefully.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your son will have my consent to marry my daughter.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your son, my lord, has paid a soldier’s debt.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: My lord, your son has paid the soldier’s price: death.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, In which so many smiling Romans bathed, Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood, and that great men shall press For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your statue spouting blood through many holes, in which many smiling Romans bathed, means that you will provide great Rome with sustaining blood.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your sword upon a woman?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Drawing your sword on a woman?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Of course I hear it.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your vessels and your spells provide, Your charms and everything beside.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You bring your cauldrons, your spells, your charms, and everything else.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your virtue is my privilege.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I rely on your virtue to protect me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your voice shall be as strong as any man’s In the disposing of new dignities.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your vote will be as strong as anyone’s in the reordering of the government.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your way is shorter.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are taking a shorter route.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your wife and brother Made wars upon me, and their contestation Was theme for you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your wife and brother led troops against me, claiming to be fighting in your name.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor Demuring upon me.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your wife Octavia, with her self-effacing eyes and self-righteous assumptions, will not receive any praise from patronizing me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your wife would give you little thanks for that If she were by to hear you make the offer.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your wife would not like it if she were here to hear you make that offer.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your will?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: What do you want?

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your wives, your daughters, Your matrons, and your maids could not fill up The cistern of my lust, and my desire All continent impediments would o'erbear That did oppose my will.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your wives, your daughters, your old women, and your young maids together could not satisfy my lust.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your Worship is deceived.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: It is not true.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth, and I praise God for you.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You speak like a very thankful and respectful boy, and may God bless you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your worship was wont to tell me that I could do nothing without bidding.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You always loved to tell me I couldn't do anything without being told.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your worship’s friend and Launcelot, sir.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: He is just Launcelot.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your worth is very dear in my regard.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: You are both very precious to me.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Your behavior is an insult to all women.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Yours by this hand.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: It was yours, I swear.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Yours in the ranks of death.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I am at your service until death.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Yours, if you talk of tales.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Yours, if we are talking about  I am leaving.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Yours, yours.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Thank you.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Young people often lose their self-control even without any help from others.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: I cannot believe that dog, that rat, that mouse, that cat could scratch me to death!

translations.Shakespearean Text: Zounds, he dies!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Let’s kill him!

translations.Shakespearean Text: Zounds, hold your peace.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Damn it, shut your mouth.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Zounds, I’ll entreat no more.
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: But listen, if

translations.Shakespearean Text: Zounds, sir, you’re robbed!
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: For God’s sake, sir, you have been robbed.

translations.Shakespearean Text: Zounds, who is there?
translations.Ground Truth Formalized: Damn it, who is there?
